title: Desfontainia
text:
Desfontainia is a <a href="genus">genus</a> of <a href="flowering%20plant">flowering plant</a>s placed currently in the family <a href="Columelliaceae">Columelliaceae</a>, though formerly in <a href="Loganiaceae">Loganiaceae</a>, <a href="Potaliaceae">Potaliaceae</a> (now subsumed in <a href="Gentianaceae">Gentianaceae</a>), or a family of its own, <a href="Desfontainiaceae">Desfontainiaceae</a>.
The genus was named for the French botanist, <a href="Ren%C3%A9%20Louiche%20Desfontaines">René Louiche Desfontaines</a>.
It is <a href="Hardiness%20%28plants%29">hardy</a> to , and requires winter protection in areas with significant frosts.
Species.
Species in the genus include:
The best known species, "D. spinosa" ('Chilean holly'), is a <a href="native%20plant">native</a> of rainforests and mountain slopes in southern <a href="Central%20America">Central America</a> and <a href="South%20America">South America</a>, occurring from <a href="Costa%20Rica">Costa Rica</a> in the north to certain islands of <a href="Tierra%20del%20Fuego">Tierra del Fuego</a> (shared by <a href="Chile">Chile</a> and <a href="Argentina">Argentina</a>) in the extreme South, being present also in <a href="Panama">Panama</a>, <a href="Colombia">Colombia</a>, <a href="Venezuela">Venezuela</a>, <a href="Peru">Peru</a>, <a href="Bolivia">Bolivia</a> and <a href="Ecuador">Ecuador</a>.
Uses include <a href="medicinal%20plant">medicinal</a> / <a href="hallucinogenic">hallucinogenic</a> purposes, a natural <a href="dye">dye</a> and as an <a href="ornamental%20plant">ornamental</a> <a href="evergreen">evergreen</a> <a href="shrub">shrub</a>. In cultivation, it will grow slowly (in 10–20 years) to some in height and width, but in the wild it can also take the form of a small <a href="tree">tree</a> and reach around .
It has glossy dark green, <a href="holly">holly-like</a> leaves, and waxy red tubular flowers, often with yellow tips, and reaching in length. The fruit is a greenish-yellow <a href="berry%20%28botany%29">berry</a> circa in diameter and contains around 44 glistening, coffee-brown seeds. It is a <a href="calcifuge">calcifuge</a> (i.e. requires a lime-free environment) and will thrive in wetter conditions in the wild than it is sometimes given credit for in the <a href="horticultural">horticultural</a> literature, occurring as it does in bogs and swamps. It is usually a <a href="terrestrial%20plant">terrestrial plant</a>, but can also grow as an <a href="epiphyte">epiphyte</a>.
Habitat.
In the <a href="Valdivian%20temperate%20rainforest">Valdivian temperate rainforest</a> of Chile and Argentina "D. spinosa" is typically found growing in the <a href="understorey">understorey</a> of forests dominated by "<a href="Nothofagus">Nothofagus</a>" (southern beech) species - particularly lenga ("<a href="Nothofagus%20pumilio">Nothofagus pumilio</a>") and coihue ("<a href="Nothofagus%20dombeyi">Nothofagus dombeyi</a>").
Epiphyte.
In 2001, "D. spinosa" was described for the first time as having been observed growing as a (fully <a href="autotrophic">autotrophic</a>) epiphyte, the host tree in question being the "lahuán / alerce" - the gigantic and extremely long-lived conifer "<a href="Fitzroya%20cupressoides">Fitzroya cupressoides</a>." The <a href="epiphyte">epiphyte</a> communities of the largest substrates (<a href="Substrate%20%28biology%29">Substrate</a> (biology)) (deep soil mats some 34 m (111 ft) up in the Fitzroya crowns), featured not only Desfontainia, but also the shrub <a href="Pseudopanax%20laetevirens">Pseudopanax laetevirens</a> (<a href="Araliaceae">Araliaceae</a>) and two tree species, namely "<a href="Tepualia%20stipularis">Tepualia stipularis</a>" (<a href="Myrtaceae">Myrtaceae</a>)and <a href="Weinmannia%20trichosperma">Weinmannia trichosperma</a> (<a href="Cunoniaceae">Cunoniaceae</a>). These normally terrestrial species were thriving in their epiphytic existence - even a tall specimen of Tepualia showed no sign of stress. Some "Fitzroya" crowns sported such large epiphytic trees as to give the impression of a 'double crown effect.'
Seed dispersal.
The sole seed-<a href="dispersal%20vector">dispersal vector</a> for both epiphytic and terrestrial populations of "Desfontainia" in the "Fitzroya" forest remnants of <a href="Chile">Chile</a> and <a href="Argentina">Argentina</a> is the chumaihuén ("<a href="Dromiciops%20gliroides">Dromiciops gliroides</a>"), an <a href="edible%20dormouse">edible dormouse</a>-like <a href="marsupial">marsupial</a> in length (including tail). This little creature, part <a href="frugivore">frugivore</a> and part <a href="insectivore">insectivore</a> forms an evolutionary link from the marsupials of South America to the marsupial fauna of Australia. It is better-known by its Spanish name "<a href="monito%20del%20monte">monito del monte</a>" (little monkey of the mountain). Largely <a href="arboreal">arboreal</a> and <a href="nocturnal">nocturnal</a>, "Dromiciops" distributes in its <a href="faeces">faeces</a> the seeds of many of the berry-bearing, <a href="endemic">endemic</a> plants present in its range, including those of not one, but two shrubs hallucinogenic to humans: "Desfontainia spinosa" (see below) and "<a href="Gaultheria">Gaultheria</a> insana," formerly known as "Pernettya furens" (<a href="Ericaceae">Ericaceae</a>).
Pollinators.
"Desfontainia spinosa," like many red-flowered plants, is pollinated by birds, the species involved being the <a href="green-backed%20firecrown">green-backed firecrown</a> - "Sephanoides sephaniodes" - the most southerly species of <a href="hummingbird">hummingbird</a>.
A <a href="bumblebee">bumblebee</a> species - "<a href="Bombus%20dahlbomii">Bombus dahlbomii</a>" is also involved. Bee species are barely receptive to red wavelengths of light i.e. greater than 600 nm, but have been found still to be able to perceive red flowers, particularly blue-ish red ones, thanks to their l-receptors. "Desfontainia" flowers are mostly of a true red (scarlet as opposed to deep pink) but, seen with the green-sensitive component of a bee's vision, still present enough of a contrast with green foliage to be noticeable and thus pollinatable. Furthermore, the yellow flower mouths of certain varieties of "Desfontainia" would be visible by bees at 590 nm. (See <a href="Bee%20learning%20and%20communication">Bee learning and communication</a> section 1.6 Neurobiology of colour vision).
"Bombus dahlbomii", a large, golden-furred species and the only one native to the South American temperate forest of southern Chile and Argentina, is now, sadly, endangered, thanks to the introduction of European "<a href="Bombus%20terrestris">Bombus terrestris</a>."
Cultivation.
"Desfontainia spinosa" was introduced into cultivation in Europe by <a href="William%20Lobb">William Lobb</a> in 1843. It has gained the <a href="Royal%20Horticultural%20Society">Royal Horticultural Society</a>'s <a href="Award%20of%20Garden%20Merit">Award of Garden Merit</a>. It requires a sheltered, partially shaded position in acid pH soil.
Uses.
"Desfontainia spinosa" has twice been reported with voucher specimens as a hallucinogen from Andean southern <a href="Colombia">Colombia</a> by <a href="Richard%20Evans%20Schultes">Richard Evans Schultes</a> : the first time in 1942 from the Paramo de Tambillo and the second from the Paramo de San Antonio in 1953.
<a href="Shamans">Shamans</a> in Colombia's <a href="Sibundoy">Sibundoy</a> Valley make a tea of the leaves 'when they want to dream' or 'to see visions and diagnose disease'. It is not used frequently, partly because of its potency, partly because the plant itself is not cultivated and must be gathered in the wild in remote <a href="p%C3%A1ramo">páramo</a>s. The Colombian name of the shrub is Borrachero de Paramo (=intoxicating plant of the mountain bog/bleak upland moor).
The <a href="Cams%C3%A1">Camsá</a> shamans of the Sibundoy Valley are also expert in the use of the dangerously toxic <a href="solanaceous">solanaceous</a> hallucinogens <a href="Brugmansia">Brugmansia</a> and <a href="Iochroma">Iochroma</a> and their occasional employment of "Desfontainia" for similar divinatory purposes (and reticence to speak of this practice) may well indicate a plant similarly toxic and difficult to use and causing a comparably unpleasant experience and after-effects.
"Desfontainia spinosa" var. "hookeri" has been reported as a <a href="narcotic">narcotic</a> utilized by the <a href="Mapuche">Mapuche</a> people of Chile by Carlos Mariani Ramirez, who also likened the bitterness of the plant to that of <a href="Gentian">Gentian</a> and mentioned its use as a yellow dye.
The greenish-yellow, <a href="baccate">baccate</a> fruit of "D. spinosa" is reputedly even more intoxicating than the foliage of the plant and is reported occasionally to have been brewed into a potently <a href="psychoactive">psychoactive</a> type of <a href="chicha">chicha</a> (see also <a href="Saliva-fermented%20beverages">Saliva-fermented beverages</a>).
Names for "Desfontainia" in the <a href="Mapuche%20language">Mapuche language</a> add to the knowledge of its appearance and folk uses in Chile: 'Taique' means 'shiny', in reference to the plant's glossy leaves; 'Chapico' means '<a href="Chili%20pepper">chilli</a> water', alluding to the plant's hot and bitter taste; 'Michay Blanco' means 'white kind of yellow tree', i.e. white shrub furnishing a yellow <a href="dye">dye</a>' ('Michay' can also designate several species of "<a href="Berberis">Berberis</a>" which not only yield yellow dyes but also have bright yellow wood and also somewhat resemble "Desfontainia" in appearance); 'Latuy' is also a name for "<a href="Latua%20pubiflora">Latua pubiflora</a>", the single species of the <a href="monotypic">monotypic</a> <a href="genus">genus</a> "Latua" (Solanaceae) <a href="endemic">endemic</a> to central Chile and used by the <a href="Machi%20%28shaman%29">Machi</a> of the Mapuche people as a hallucinogen and poison to cause insanity (sometimes permanent) in a victim - which accords well with its "Brugmansia"-like content of <a href="tropane%20alkaloids">tropane alkaloids</a>.
A test for alkaloids with Dragendorff's <a href="reagent">reagent</a> (see <a href="Johann%20Georg%20Noel%20Dragendorff">Johann Georg Noel Dragendorff</a>) on samples of "Desfontainia" from herbarium specimens collected in Argentina, Chile and Ecuador did not, however, indicate the presence of alkaloids, tropane or otherwise; and, while the chemistry of "Desfontainia" is becoming better known, none of the compounds isolated from it thus far can account for the plant's purported hallucinogenic effects.
Chemistry.
<a href="Chemotaxonomy">Chemotaxonomically</a>, "Desfontainia" has been historically placed in the family Loganiaceae, but it is currently assigned to Columelliaceae.
"Desfontainia spinosa" has been found to contain, among other compounds including the <a href="cucurbitacin">cucurbitacin</a>s <a href="spinoside">spinoside</a> A and B. These bitter <a href="steroids">steroids</a>, while not hallucinogenic, could contribute to the relative toxicity of the plant for human subjects, given that cucurbitacins exhibit <a href="cytotoxicity">cytotoxicity</a> and that certain kinds have been held responsible for cases of poisoning, some fatal, by dangerously irritant/cathartic plants in the plant family <a href="Cucurbitaceae">Cucurbitaceae</a> such as "<a href="Ecballium%20elaterium">Ecballium elaterium</a>" and "<a href="Citrullus%20colocynthis">Citrullus colocynthis</a>".
One chemical constituent of "Desfontainia" present in considerable quantity is the pentacyclic <a href="triterpene">triterpene</a> acid <a href="ursolic%20acid">ursolic acid</a>.
Also present are <a href="loganin">loganin</a> and <a href="secoxyloganin">secoxyloganin</a>, compounds related to <a href="secologanin">secologanin</a> a molecule involved in the <a href="mevalonate%20pathway">mevalonate pathway</a> leading to, "<a href="inter%20alia">inter alia</a>", terpenoid and steroid <a href="biosynthesis">biosynthesis</a>.
<a href="Liriodendrin">Liriodendrin</a> a ligan diglucoside also found in "<a href="Liriodendron%20tulipifera">Liriodendron tulipifera</a>" (Magnoliaceae) and "<a href="Acanthopanax%20senticosus">Acanthopanax senticosus</a>" (<a href="Araliaceae">Araliaceae</a>). Liriodendrin is transformed "<a href="in%20vivo">in vivo</a>" to <a href="syringaresinol">syringaresinol</a> which also occurs in "<a href="Castela%20emoryi">Castela emoryi</a>", "<a href="Prunus%20mume">Prunus mume</a>" and "<a href="Magnolia%20thailandica">Magnolia thailandica</a>".
